title: Remove win and lose from the game
body:
And implement the player rating as what determines what score you get for your game. I have my reasons.

I have had plenty of games where I get A or S rank and a lose, that is not fair that I have a great game and get bad team mates who lose the game for the team.

There are those games when you get premades on your team and all they do is complain about the non premades, than play terrible and lose.

There are the AFK and DC players who make it that much harder for everyone else.

There are those surprise 20 minute GG for no reason, even if your team is not losing, than you realise all 4 of your team were premade and just can't be bothered trying because the game has not already been won. Or they are trying a new comp and want to try something else, so they just GG.

Than there are those reallllyyyy close games that could have gone either way and you feel ripped of by some shit that made you lose, you get your S rank and for what? Nothing because once you hit rank 5 that ranking system is pointless.

I have Master Yi on 41K champion points, that is 21K higher than rank 5 and for what? The only time those points mean anything is when someone goes and checks your profile, after the game is over. They need to mean something other than rank. Anyone can farm a champion and get the rank up, it doesn't actually mean you are good with them.

I mean come on, I have Teemo at Rank 4 and he is useless outside laning phase in most games. Those after game scores should show how good you are, change you rank, your MMR, give your profile a score instead of a simple win or lose, there are too many variables in a team game to use a 1v1 scoring metric.

After all, don't those ranks show how you played based on ALL your stats AND a comparison against everyone else in your region in that same role with that same champion, possibly with that same matchup? That will be perfect, you get scored and given a profile score based on how YOU play with your team and against the enemy compared to everyone else on the server, not just "Hey you lost, not your fault, but too bad".

I had a really good game recently, got tons of CS, damage and all that, but a few too high deaths, yet the rank was something like C. I have had games I thought were worse than that and gotten a higher score. That is due to the champion I was playing was not up to scratch with what everyone else could do on the same server.

There are also those games where I play really bad, die a lot, get shit stats, low kills and what? I get a D rank and a win I did not deserve.

replies.body:
You play master Yi and Teemo, and you're calling for players to be ranked by performance ie. KDA

I'm 100% certain you might have some decent individual skill but abysmal team focus. It's a team game. Learn to play as a part of a team. 

With your system, everyone would be gagging to steal each others kills. Gone would be the days where braum would put himself between his adc and the enemy jinx ult. Gone would be the days where Leona would dive the tower to secure a double kill for her adc. 

'You want wards? Nah mate buy them yourself. I gotta put my money on defensive stats so I don't die. All about my individual stats, don't care if you get ganked'

I have seen players with no kills and tons of deaths get a good scores, well a good score according to them. That is because they are playing support and the idea is not to get kills, but to get your AD fed and help support your team.

Based on what role you are playing and how well you play in that role compared to others will give you your score.
So the Leona that goes 10/3/5 would not get a better personal score than the one that goes 0/9/15?

If she goes as support and takes support items than the one with the assists should get a better score. After all she did help her ADC or someone on her team get 15 kills.

That means rather than her getting all the kills, someone who can actually carry the team late will get the kills, the gold, the items and be of more use to the team.

Assists on a support champion are worth more than kills, regardless of the deaths, the 15 assists is better. I have had someone in a similar situation state he got a good score like that.

No mate. The game is just code. No code can recognise when I flash in front of a thresh hook to save my team, or eat a cait ult, or peel Yi off of my carry, or time a stun to cancel a malz ult. Etc...

Edit - heck, even well placed encouragement can change the result of a game. How's the supposed to measure that?

As per my post below:

At the end of your game, you can hover over your Champion Mastery points bar to see the grade our new system gives you. These grades are awarded based on your overall performance in the role, the champion you're playing and, crucially, where you're playing them. For example, we look at an Annie going mid differently from an Annie going support. We take a series of performance metrics and compare how you did to all other players in your region in that specific champion/position combination.

This is percentile-driven; earning a high score means you performed in the top x% of players in that champion/position combination.

That above is from Riot, they can detect how well you played compared to everyone else in your role and lane and champion and whatever. Whilst the game cannot recognise everything, there are ways to recognise some stuff that won't be implemented, like the flash > eat an ult scenario, the amount of times I have flashed and eaten an ult in error.

But non the less, the game can compare you with someone else in your same position and that should be used to an advantage of players. Let's take the best Mundo in the game, someone who plays high rank, put him into Bronze, on his own he won't get out, no matter how good that person played.
Everyone starts somewhere. That high rank Mundo was a newbie once. He got to where he is now by himself. The myth that no one can get out of bronze is bs
shh he just want's to keep his circle jerk going with the other bronzies on boards.

Out of curiosity, how would the game know if a champion is being played as a support or as another role?  I've seen some people use Lulu in top lane, while Veigar has potential as a support.  I've also seen plenty of supports bringing ignite instead of exhaust, while mid laners bringing exhaust instead of ignite, so checking by summoner spell isn't really an answer either.

There is a way, there will always be a way I just don't know how exactly. The game would be able to recognise what lane you are in. Straight outta Riots book:

At the end of your game, you can hover over your Champion Mastery points bar to see the grade our new system gives you. These grades are awarded based on your overall performance in the role, the champion you're playing and, crucially, where you're playing them. For example, we look at an Annie going mid differently from an Annie going support. We take a series of performance metrics and compare how you did to all other players in your region in that specific champion/position combination.

This is percentile-driven; earning a high score means you performed in the top x% of players in that champion/position combination.
Actually, I do notice the lane on that hover, but the role is wrong every single time for mine.
I don't think the game actually tells you what lane they think you were playing in, not that I have ever came across at least.

All you do is complain about this game.

Pretty sure if that's all you're doing, and since your complaints are pretty much "It's a team game, but I can't win by treating it like a ME game". You need to go and find another game.

You call is complaining, I am trying to provide feedback and an actual effort to change this game to make it better.

As good as this game is being a team game and all, how many games have you played that resulted in a lose because of your 'team'?

I can only say a handful of my games of late have been good games on both sides and I genuinely had fun in.

It is a TEAM game and should only be considered as such.

It doesn't matter if one person doesn't deserve to win, that's how it works.

I go play TF2, a game I've been in the pro leagues for and won plenty of tournaments, and without trying I get over 150 points in 30 minutes from just playing casually and the next highest in the game will be 40 points at best.
My team doesn't always win just because I have such a huge score.
You have to press objectives to win, you have to go for the end game goal, or bust.
+1 can confirm this happens to me too. You do well in game, you still lose simply because your team isn't as fed as you, they die quickly leaving you to 1v5 what are you going to do then?
